nodes.name: Does it have an end date?
Does it have an end date?1
Does it have an end date?2
Does it have an end date?3
Add 1 day to end date
nodes.notes:
Google Calendar and Notion handle end dates differently, when there's no time set.

If a date in Notion is from Nov-10 to Nov-12, in Google it will show "Nov-10 at 00:00" to "Nov-12 at 00:00".
Meaning the event would end at the beggining of the day in Nov-12, not lasting all day.

So to make an event last all day in Nov-12 you have to make the end_date "Nov-13 at 00:00".

nodes.name: Add 1 day to end date1
nodes.notes:
Google Calendar and Notion handle end dates differently, when there's no time set.

If a date in Notion is from Nov-10 to Nov-12, in Google it will show "Nov-10 at 00:00" to "Nov-12 at 00:00".
Meaning the event would end at the beggining of the day in Nov-12, not lasting all day.

So to make an event last all day in Nov-12 you have to make the end_date "Nov-13 at 00:00".

nodes.name: Page edited by a user?
nodes.notes:
This prevents infinite loops of pages being edited by n8n and triggering the workflow again and again.
It will only update Google Calendar events when a user edits the Notion pages.

nodes.name: Calculate timeDifference between Google's updated_at  and our own updated_at fields
Only events that were edited 2s after the last update
nodes.notes:
This prevents an infinite loop.

When you edit your Notion page, our automation edits the Google event. This would activate the Google trigger again and again.

Using the field "lastUpdatedByAutomation" we can check if the update happened after our automation ran. Meaning the user was the one that edited the event.

nodes.name: Subtract 1 day from end_date
nodes.notes:
Google Calendar and Notion handle end dates differently, when there's no time set.

If a date in Notion is from Nov-10 to Nov-12, in Google it will show "Nov-10 at 00:00" to "Nov-12 at 00:00".

When you set an event in Google from Nov-12 to Nov-13, it sets the end date to "Nov-14 at 00:00" behind the scenes.
Meaning the event would end at the beggining of Nov-14, lasting all day long during Nov-13.

But Notion considers Nov-12 to Nov-13 already as all day dates.
So Nov-14 in Google must be Nov-13 in Notion.

nodes.name: Does it really have an end_date?
Subtract 1 day from end_date1
nodes.notes:
Google Calendar and Notion handle end dates differently, when there's no time set.

If a date in Notion is from Nov-10 to Nov-12, in Google it will show "Nov-10 at 00:00" to "Nov-12 at 00:00".

When you set an event in Google from Nov-12 to Nov-13, it sets the end date to "Nov-14 at 00:00" behind the scenes.
Meaning the event would end at the beggining of Nov-14, lasting all day long during Nov-13.

But Notion considers Nov-12 to Nov-13 already as all day dates.
So Nov-14 in Google must be Nov-13 in Notion.
